awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Novel Tubular Proton Exchange Fuel Cell Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a novel tubular proton exchange fuel cell and potential commercialization for applications ranging from portable electronics to transport applications. Fuel cells are expected to play a significant role in zero-emission power generation and in the expansion of the hydrogen industry and clean energy, with the global market size projected to reach $25.5 billion by 2024. However, current planar fuel cell designs have challenges before they can be compatible with the Department of Energy targets for specific power, performance, cost, and durability. The proposed technology may address a number of these challenges due to its novel tubular design.

This I-Corps project is based on the potential development of a proposed tubular proton exchange fuel cell, which due to its novel design, could offer reduced weight and improved specific power as well as reduced complexity, and reduced cost compared to the conventional planar fuel cell design. The technology may also offer improved reactant mass transport, possibly improved efficient product water removal, and may possess improved uniform reactant, current and temperature distribution. In this technology, structure-property-performance-degradation correlations for conventional, planar, agglomerate-type fuel cells, as well as carbon nanofiber-based fuel cells, could also be established to help guide the future rational design of efficient and stable components for zero-emission systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on developing and commercializing a prototype of a novel tubular proton exchange membrane fuel cell (T-PEMFC) for applications ranging from portable electronics to micro-mobility and transportation. The proposed fuel cell offers a disruptive design that addresses current limitations of planar fuel cells, such as challenges related to weight, mass transport and cost. With fuel cells expected to play a major role in zero-emission power generation and the hydrogen industry rapidly growing, the success of this project has the potential to contribute significantly to the clean energy sector.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the scientific discovery and fundamental understanding that resulted from the design, modeling, and testing of novel components in the tubular fuel cell. Due to the new design, the T-PEMFC offers approximately 50% reduced weight and increased specific power compared to conventional planar designs.

The technical aspect of the project was enriched by the team participation in the NSF I-Corps program, funded by this award, which has provided valuable entrepreneurial and market validation training. By aligning the fuel cell design with customer needs, the team has been able to generate creative solutions and pivot its business model to better fit market demands.

The research will contribute broadly to fuel cell technology development by advancing knowledge in the field and offering a new alternative to the conventional planar designs. Key findings from the project will include structure-property-performance-degradation correlations for various fuel cell types, guiding future rational designs of zero-emission systems.

Broader Impact

This project’s broader impacts are far-reaching, contributing significantly to the transition toward a zero-emission and sustainable future. The tubular fuel cell has a wide range of applications, including portable electronics, micro-mobility devices, drones, and decentralized power generation systems. Furthermore, the lightweight and efficient nature of the tubular PEMFC makes it particularly suitable for applications in planes, drones, trains, and ships, offering potential for broader market penetration despite the expected slow pace of adoption in some sectors.

In addition to the technological advancements, this project plays a crucial role in training future leaders and entrepreneurs in clean energy. Students and postdoctoral researchers involved in the project have gained invaluable experience through the NSF I-Corps training program. They participated in market research, patent applications, and collaboration with the University of Connecticut’s Technology Incubation Program (TIP). Their work involved conducting more than 168 interviews with potential users and industry leaders, which helped them sharpen their commercialization strategies, communication skills, and technical expertise. These experiences have not only enhanced the students' entrepreneurial skills but have also paved the way for future career opportunities, such as PhD studies and collaborations with industry partners.

The project has also facilitated collaborations with leading fuel cell institutions and industrial partners. Visits to European and North American companies and institutions, as well as attendance to several international conferences, have provided valuable insights into market needs and technical challenges.

The project’s outcomes and findings span several key areas:

  1. Prototype Development: A significant achievement has been the development of a prototype for the tubular PEMFC. The team made notable progress by developing the cathode for the cell and running ANSYS simulations to optimize the design. The next steps involve finalizing the prototype and testing it in collaboration with industrial partners, which will provide third-party testing.
  2. Market Validation and Pivot: The I-Corps training provided the team with insights into customer needs and market segments. Originally targeting electric bikes and scooters, the team pivoted after realizing that the drone market offered a better fit for their T- PEMFC. Specifically, delivery and survey drones emerged as a key market segment, with strong interest in lightweight and efficient energy solutions for these applications. Over 200 interviews conducetd in total, helped solidify this decision.
  3. Intellectual Property Protection: The team filed a provisional patent for the T-PEMFC design, securing intellectual property protection for their novel technology. Once the prototype is finalized and tested, a full patent will be filed to ensure that the technology is safeguarded as it moves toward commercialization.
  4. Training and Career Development: The project has had a profound impact on the career trajectories of its team members. The project supported development of two PhD students, a Master’s student, and a postdoc, which all gained valuable experience through their leadership roles in the I-Corps program, their involvement in the technical development of the fuel cell, as well as IP process of filing a patent.
  5. Collaborations and Partnerships: The project has established strong relationships with industrial and academic partners. These collaborations are essential for advancing the development and commercialization of the tubular PEMFC. The team's visits to fuel cell institutions and conferences in Germany, Belgium, Canada, Spain, and Mexico have generated significant interest in the technology, particularly for applications in drones and transportation.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2024
Modified by: Jasna Jankovic
